title-group.article-title: Factors influencing the psychological well-being of patients undergoing haemodialysis in Taiwan: an observational study

contrib-group.aff: 1Collage of Nursing, National Defense Medical University, Taipei, Taiwan

See: http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc/4.0/.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: We aimed to understand the factors affecting psychological well-being of patients undergoing haemodialysis (HD). First, we explored how physical symptom severity, emotional distress and social support influence psychological well-being. Second, we examined the impact of different types of social support. Third, we investigated whether any variables mediate the relationship with psychological well-being.

sec.title: Design and setting
sec.p: A cross-sectional study, a type of observational design, was conducted on patients at a medical centre in Taiwan in 2020.

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: A total of 117 outpatients who had undergone regular HD for at least 3 months were enrolled.

sec.title: Primary outcome measures
sec.p: The psychological well-being was assessed through self-report questionnaires.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: We found that emotional distress (β=−0.25, p=0.033) had a significant negative impact on psychological well-being. However, the presence of appraisal support mitigated this effect. Specifically, appraisal support fully mediated the adverse impact of emotional distress on psychological well-being. In addition, the severity of physical symptoms was generally mild and did not influence psychological well-being.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Receiving appraisal support from family, friends and healthcare professionals not only alleviates emotional distress but also enhances psychological well-being both directly and indirectly among patients undergoing HD. Healthcare professionals should address issues of personal importance while serving as consultants, educators and evaluators to support patients in managing their chronic condition.

caption.title: STRENGTHS AND LIMITATIONS OF THIS STUDY

list-item.p: Data were collected from patients in Taiwan, which has the highest global prevalence of haemodialysis, through a face-to-face process to enhance data integrity.
The results were adjusted by a propensity score to reduce selection bias and minimise the inter-relationship between individuals’ characteristics and psychological well-being.
The use of both regression and mediation analyses provided a comprehensive understanding of the predictors and underlying mechanisms influencing psychological well-being in this population.
The strength of the mediation model was evaluated, and high statistical power confirmed the robustness of the result.
The cross-sectional design and non-probability sampling from a single medical centre may limit the generalisability of the findings.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Chronic kidney disease is an increasing global health threat, ranking as the 11th leading cause of age-standardised death worldwide in 2021.1 The global prevalence of chronic kidney disease has been estimated to be 9.1% (8.5%–9.8%), with 0.041% (0.037%–0.044%) of individuals undergoing dialysis in 2017.2 For several years, Taiwan has had the highest global prevalence of dialysis and haemodialysis (HD), with rates of 0.377% and 0.348%, respectively, in 2020. Furthermore, these rates have continued to increase annually.3 4 The 5-year survival rate among individuals undergoing HD is 53.5% in Taiwan, 42.0% in the USA and 38.9% in Canada.3 Patients undergoing HD experience various forms of physical and psychosocial distress throughout their lives that are associated with poor outcomes and are a significant public health concern.246

Patients undergoing HD were required to undergo dialysis every 2–3 days to sustain life, with no choice but to adhere to this routine, regardless of the circumstances. In addition, they need to regularly undergo medical tests, lab tests and outpatient visits, all of which, along with the cost of dialysis, can lead to significant financial burdens.7 8 Furthermore, patients experience uraemic toxicity, water-electrolyte imbalance and rapid body fluid and electrolyte changes during HD, which cause various physical symptoms.5 Patients undergoing HD have to adapt to their reliance on dialysis for life support, leading to changes in their lifestyles and roles, which in turn promote emotional distress and suicidal ideation.9 Quality of life, which is one dimension of psychological well-being, has been shown to be significantly impaired in patients undergoing HD.1013 However, there are limited data on the psychological well-being of patients undergoing HD. Psychological well-being is an indicator of the balance between challenging and rewarding life events and is a multidimensional factor that is considered when making country-level policies related to overall health.13 14 Improving psychological well-being among patients undergoing HD is crucial because of the increased prevalence of HD, the prolonged life expectancy of patients undergoing HD and the various symptoms that these patients experience.14 15

Theoretically, social support buffers the impact of stressful events and moderates the impact of genetic and environmental factors on distress.16 The mechanisms by which social support enhances resilience against stress among patients undergoing HD include various neurobiological factors, effective coping strategies and motivation to navigate life challenges. Social support mitigates the unfavourable effects of adverse life events and persistent challenges.1618 Furthermore, social support contributes to positive psychological well-being by improving health behaviours and promoting appropriate emotional adaptation strategies, which can lead to a reduction in physical and emotional distress in patients with chronic diseases.14 19 However, a meta-analytic review reported that enhancing social support had no effects on improving psychological well-being.20 The inconsistency in the literature may stem from the fact that there are various forms of social support, and only some may be effective in enhancing psychological well-being. Therefore, we aimed to identify the factors and types of social support that influence psychological well-being among patients undergoing HD. Moreover, we examined the mediating effect of social support on psychological well-being.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: In this cross-sectional study, data were collected from a convenience sample in an HD unit at a medical centre in Taiwan between January 2020 and December 2020. We aimed to identify the influence of physical symptom severity, emotional distress and social support on psychological well-being. The inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) individuals diagnosed with end-stage renal disease; (2) outpatients who had undergone HD for at least 3 months; (3) individuals aged ≥20 years and (4) individuals who were undergoing HD at least two times a week. The exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) a history of cancer and (2) receiving hospice care. Patients with a history of cancer were excluded because those undergoing haemodialysis with a concurrent cancer diagnosis are often at a terminal stage or undergoing cancer-specific treatments, which may significantly influence psychological outcomes. Therefore, to ensure that the findings more accurately reflect the general haemodialysis population, these patients were excluded. Data were collected anonymously using self-report questionnaires administered through a face-to-face procedure. During the process, the researchers assisted participants in completing the questionnaires only when necessary, such as when participants were unable or found it difficult to read or write. If participants were able to complete the questionnaires independently, the researchers refrained from interfering. On completion, the researchers quickly checked the questionnaires and asked participants whether any missing responses were intentional. Each participant completed the questionnaires once during the study period. Using G*Power for sample size calculation, with α=0.05, power=0.8 and an effect size of 0.3, the minimum required sample size was 82.21

sec.title: Patient and public involvement
sec.p: None.

sec.title: Basic information
sec.p: Basic information, including demographic and disease characteristics, was collected from patients. The demographic data included sex, age, marital status, education level and economic status. The disease characteristics included the duration of HD (in years) and comorbidities, which were measured by the Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI); high CCI values indicate more severe comorbidities.22

sec.title: Physical symptom severity
sec.p: Using symptoms identified in the Kidney Disease Quality of Life instrument, along with symptoms commonly reported in the literature and by patients, we developed the Physical Symptom Severity Scale to assess the physical symptoms experienced by patients undergoing HD.5 23 The scale includes 18 items related to the following common physical symptoms that have been reported by patients undergoing HD: difficulty falling asleep, ease of awakening from sleep, dry skin, itchy skin, dry mouth, chest pain, shortness of breath, cramps, muscle soreness, muscle weakness, numbness in the hands or feet, joint pain, dizziness, fatigue, headache, poor appetite, nausea/vomiting and constipation/diarrhoea. Each item is scored on a 4-point Likert scale (0, none; 1, mild; 2, moderate; 3, severe) to indicate the severity of each physical symptom that a patient has experienced during the past 2 weeks. A higher score indicates greater physical symptom severity. The internal consistency of the Physical Symptom Severity Scale measured was 0.89.

sec.title: Emotional distress
sec.p: Emotional distress was measured by the Brief Symptom Rating Scale (BSRS-5). This self-report scale assesses the level of distress caused by five symptoms—anxiety, depression, hostility, interpersonal sensitivity/inferiority and insomnia—experienced in the past week.24 The items are scored on a 5-point Likert scale (0, not at all; 1, a little bit; 2, moderately; 3, quite a bit and 4, extremely), with a higher score indicating greater severity of emotional distress.

sec.title: Social support
sec.p: The short-form version of the Interpersonal Support Evaluation List (ISEL-SF) was used to assess perceived social support. The ISEL-SF includes 16 items that had the highest factor loadings within each of the four subscales of the original ISEL.25 26 The four subscales were as follows: the perceived availability of someone to discuss issues of personal importance (appraisal support; AP), the perceived availability of material aid (tangible asset support; TA), the perceived availability of others to interact socially (belonging support; BE) and the the perceived availability of others with whom one compares favorably (self-esteem support; SE).27 The ISEL-SF was modified from a 4-point rating scale (definitely true, probably true, probably false and definitely false; scored from 0 to 3 points), with higher scores indicating greater perceived social support.26

sec.title: Psychological well-being
sec.p: Well-being was measured using the 18-item Psychological Well-Being (PWB) scale, which measures six aspects of well-being: autonomy, environmental mastery, personal growth, positive relations with others, purpose in life and self-acceptance.28 The respondents rated the extent to which they agreed or disagreed with each item on a 6-point Likert scale ranging from 1 (‘completely disagree’) to 6 (‘completely agree’). Higher scores indicate greater well-being, and separate subscale scores were calculated by summing the scores of all the items within each subscale.

sec.title: Data analysis
sec.p: The data were analysed using SPSS V.23.0 for Windows. Psychological well-being scores were confirmed to follow a normal distribution using the Kolmogorov-Smirnov test. First, we explored how physical symptom severity, emotional distress and social support influence psychological well-being using univariate analyses. Then, a multiple regression model was employed to examine independent predictors of psychological well-being. At this stage, due to inter-relationships among demographic variables, we applied propensity score adjustment to reduce potential confounding. The propensity scores were derived from a logistic regression model accounting for sex, age, CCI and years on haemodialysis. To further explore the underlying mechanisms, mediation analysis was conducted using the PROCESS macro version 3.5 for SPSS, with bootstrapping procedures used to estimate indirect effects. This analysis assessed whether any variables mediated the relationship with psychological well-being. While the regression analysis identified direct associations, the mediation analysis provided insight into indirect pathways, particularly the role of social support. The statistical power of the mediation model was further assessed using MedPower software.29 All tests were two-tailed, with statistical significance set at p<0.05.

sec.title: Distribution of demographic and disease characteristics
sec.p: A total of 117 patients, aged between 29 and 89 years, were enrolled in the study. All participants completed the study procedures, resulting in a response rate of 100%. The percentage of men slightly exceeded that of women, aligning with the overall trend observed among patients undergoing HD in Taiwan.30 Most patients (62.4%) were aged 51–70 years, 73.5% had 12 or fewer years of education, and two-thirds were financially independent. In terms of disease characteristics, the CCI scores ranged from 2 to 7 points, and 26.5% of the patients had a CCI score greater than 3 points. The participants had undergone dialysis for 0.6–28.7 years and underwent regular dialysis two or three times per week. Results showed that patients’ demographic and disease characteristics were not associated with the psychological well-being (table 1).

caption.title: Description of the patients’ demographic and disease characteristics, and their association with the psychological well-being

fn.p: CCI, Charlson Comorbidity Index; HD, haemodialysis; PWB, Psychological Well-Being.

sec.title: Distribution of physical symptom severity, emotional distress and social support scores
sec.p: The patients’ physical symptom severity score ranged from 0 to 39 points (M=10.6, SD=8.2).

The first five severe symptoms were in order of dry skin, difficulty falling asleep, skin pruritus, ease of awakening from sleep, numbness in the limbs and fatigue (table 2). We found that physical symptom severity (r=−0.72, p=0.44) was not associated with psychological well-being. In terms of emotional distress, the total BSRS-5 score of the patients ranged from 0 to 18 points (M=3.0, SD=3.0). The result showed that emotional distress (r=−0.24, p=0.008) was negatively correlated with the psychological well-being.

caption.title: Description of the patients’ physical symptom severity scores

sec.p: Regarding social support, the total ISEL-SF score ranged from 11 to 48 points (M=33.4, SD=7.9). The mean scores of the AP, TA, BE and SE subscales were 8.5, 9.3, 7.0 and 8.7 points, respectively. There was a significant positive correlation between psychological well-being and social support (r=0.39, p<0.001). Among the social support subscales, the AP subscale (r=0.41, p<0.001), TA subscale (r=0.37, p<0.001) and SE subscale (r=0.30, p=0.001) were significantly associated with psychological well-being, while the BE subscale (r=0.17, p=0.66) was not.

sec.title: Psychological well-being
sec.p: The total PWB scale score ranged from 49 to 108 points (M=86.9, SD=12.4). In terms of the six well-being subscales, the scores ranging from highest to lowest were as follows: environmental mastery (M=15.9, SD=2.6), personal growth (M=14.7, SD=3.1), positive relationships with others (M=14.6, SD=3.0), autonomy (M=14.2, SD=3.5), self-acceptance (M=13.9, SD=2.9) and purpose in life (M=13.6, SD=3.5).

sec.title: Factors affecting psychological well-being in patients undergoing HD
sec.p: Table 3 shows the results of the multiple regression analyses. Physical symptom severity did not affect psychological well-being. Social support (β=0.33, p<0.001) had a positive effect, while emotional distress (β=−0.25, p=0.033) had a negative impact on psychological well-being (Model 1). To further examine the specific contributions of different types of social support, we used subscale scores in the regression analysis. Regarding the social support subscales, only AP (β=0.29, p=0.007) significantly and positively affected psychological well-being (Model 2). In the presence of AP, the effect of emotional distress on psychological well-being became non-significant (β=−0.22, p=0.060).

caption.title: Regression analysis of factors influencing psychological well-being

sec.p: In our analysis, physical symptom severity was not a significant predictor of psychological well-being in the initial regression model. As it did not meet the prerequisite criteria for mediation analysis, it was excluded from subsequent mediation testing. Mediation analysis demonstrated that AP fully mediated the relationship between emotional distress and psychological well-being (figure 1). The statistical power of the mediation model was calculated to be 0.813.

caption.title: Appraisal support fully mediates the relationship between emotional distress and psychological well-being. *p<0.05; **p<0.01; ***p<0.001; β, standardised coefficient; c, total effect of emotional distress on psychological well-being; c′, direct effect of emotional distress on psychological well-being while adjusting for appraisal support.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Our findings indicated that emotional distress and social support were significant predictors of psychological well-being. Among the various types of support, appraisal support emerged as the most influential factor, demonstrating both direct and indirect effects. Notably, appraisal support fully mediated the relationship between emotional distress and psychological well-being. The combined use of regression and mediation analyses facilitated a comprehensive evaluation of both the predictors and the underlying mechanisms influencing psychological well-being.

In terms of psychological well-being in patients undergoing HD, the three subscales with the lowest scores were the purpose in life, self-acceptance and autonomy subscales. Patients undergoing HD must undergo dialysis 2–3 times a week for the rest of their lives, with each session lasting 3–4 hours. These treatments reduced their quality of life and limited their autonomy in daily activities.31 32 Patients also reported encountering a range of challenges, including physical and psychosocial problems, alterations in their appearance due to the presence of arteriovenous fistulae and skin hyperpigmentation, modifications to their lifestyles and social activities that involved dietary and fluid intake restrictions, and constraints on their time and activities due to the demands of dialysis. All of these challenges negatively impacted patients’ self-acceptance, autonomy and sense of purpose.3 33 34

We found that the severity of physical symptoms did not impact psychological well-being. This finding was inconsistent with previous studies, which indicated that individuals with more severe sleep issues, more physical symptoms, greater illness severity and worse health status tended to have lower quality of life and diminished well-being.313538 Our results may be attributed to the mild nature of our patients’ physical symptoms, leading to a weaker effect on psychological well-being. Taiwan has universal National Health Insurance (NHI), which has covered more than 99% of the total population since 1995; furthermore, 8.7%–9.2% of the total NHI costs are associated with patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD).2 In Taiwan, patients undergoing HD and treatment for ESRD-related illnesses incur minimal costs, as the NHI covers most expenses.2 39 Patients undergoing HD in Taiwan show better physical function and experience less pain than those in the USA.32 One possible explanation is that Taiwanese patients have unrestricted access to medical treatment and healthcare services, including ESRD care initiatives, dialysis, and vascular access management, without the concern of financial barriers.40 Unlike previous studies reporting significant financial burdens for patients undergoing HD, 61.4% of participants in our study were unemployed or retired, yet approximately two-thirds reported financial independence. Contrary to the literature, we also found that financial status did not affect psychological well-being.7 8 Healthcare policy and national medical insurance could significantly reduce the severity of physical symptoms and the financial burden of patients undergoing HD.

Patients undergoing HD need to cope with challenges related to changes in their symptoms, appearance, restricted roles, limited activity engagement, impaired functioning and career changes, all of which can further exacerbate emotional distress.334143 Our findings revealed a negative correlation between emotional distress and psychological well-being, consistent with the findings of previous studies highlighting that emotional distress often leads to an increased incidence of mental disorders and a decline in quality of life among individuals with chronic diseases.9 44 A previous systematic review reported that the use of cognitive behavioural therapy, exercise and relaxation techniques likely decreases depressive symptoms in dialysis patients.45 However, complex emotional regulation emphasises the tuning of higher brain centres, including cortical centres, the amygdala, the medial frontal cortex and top-down control.46 The management of emotional distress is linked to individuals’ personalities, coping methods and personal experiences, all of which are difficult to modify.47 48 Moreover, we found that appraisal support fully mediated the effect of emotional distress on psychological well-being. Appraisal support, defined as the perception of having someone to discuss personal matters with in a patient-centred manner, was found to have a positive effect on psychological well-being. Patients undergoing HD face numerous physical, psychological and daily life challenges, making supportive conversations essential for their well-being. Appraisal support from trusted sources enhances psychological well-being by strengthening internal coping mechanisms, helping individuals adapt to role changes and managing shifts in family responsibilities caused by long-term dialysis or related complications.38 49 Over time, offering appraisal support can help manage chronic illnesses, reduce emotional distress, improve quality of life and further enhance the psychological well-being of patients undergoing HD.

Both our theoretical and practical findings can be applied by healthcare professionals to provide appraisal support during the communication and consultation process. First, healthcare professionals should develop their communication and consultation skills through clinical practice curricula in both medical education programmes and continuing education programmes. Second, tutors should practise and provide feedback on communication and consultation skills regarding patient-centred care in clinical learning settings, such as training courses, modelling, role-playing, instructional videos and informational handouts. Additionally, supervisors should evaluate healthcare professionals’ communication and consultation skills to assess their ability to provide patient-centred support, which involves assessing patients’ social support needs, engaging with them and delivering appropriate informational, appraisal, instrumental and emotional support.50 Healthcare professionals, particularly physicians and nurses, should recognise patients’ concerns, listen to their challenges and worries, address symptoms that may frequently change, confirm adherence to treatment, respect their values and provide consistent support to nurture a trusting relationship. These actions can collectively enhance psychological well-being among individuals undergoing HD. In addition to healthcare professionals, it is crucial to engage family members, friends and neighbours as significant sources of social support to enhance the psychological well-being of patients undergoing HD.18 38

This study has several strengths. First, data were collected through a face-to-face process to assist participants who had difficulty reading or writing the questionnaire, thereby enhancing data accuracy and integrity, without influencing their responses. Additionally, as this study did not involve sensitive topics such as healthcare quality or patient satisfaction, there was no bias introduced by the face-to-face data collection methodology. Second, results were adjusted by a propensity score to reduce the inter-relationship between potentially confounding variables and psychological well-being. Third, we identified a more modifiable mediating factor and showed that it has high power for further implications in clinical practice. Although potential confounders were accounted for, there are still some limitations. The current study applied a cross-sectional design and used a non-probability sampling method to recruit participants from a medical centre. Future studies should use a longitudinal design to assess the trend of psychological well-being among patients undergoing HD in the future. We only included 117 patients; however, the sex ratio in our study closely matches that of all patients undergoing HD in Taiwan. The results of this study can serve as a reference for healthcare professionals to enhance the psychological well-being of patients undergoing HD.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our research revealed that providing appraisal support can enhance psychological well-being both directly and indirectly, reducing the negative impact of emotional distress. Healthcare professionals should offer appraisal support to patients undergoing HD, taking on roles as consultants, educators and evaluators to help patients manage chronic disease.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors would like to thank the staff of the HD room for their administrative support, as well as Professor Sen-Yeong Kao from the College of Public Health, National Defense Medical University, for his valuable guidance during the research design and statistical analysis process.

fn.p: Funding: This study was supported by grants from the Tri-Service General Hospital (TSGH_D_114205) and the Ministry of National Defense, Taiwan (MND-MAB-D-114153). The funders had no role in the manuscript preparation or publication decision.
Prepublication history for this paper is available online. To view these files, please visit the journal online (https://doi.org/10.1136/bmjopen-2024-095840).
Data availability free text: The data presented in this study cannot be made publicly available due to the lack of approval from our ethics committee.
Patient consent for publication: Consent obtained directly from patient(s).

Ethics approval: This study involves human participants and was approved. The study was approved by the Institutional Review Board of the Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital (No. 200191003R). Participants gave informed consent to participate in the study before taking part.
Provenance and peer review: Not commissioned; externally peer reviewed.
Patient and public involvement: Patients and/or the public were not involved in the design, or conduct, or reporting, or dissemination plans of this research.

sec.title: Data availability statement
sec.p: Due to restrictions imposed by the Institutional Review Board (IRB), the data from this study are not publicly available.
